Award.AwardTitle: Scalable Nanomanufacturing of Hierarchical Inorganic-Polymer Hybrid Electrodes for Next Generation High-Energy Lithium-Ion Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developing electrochemical energy storage devices with high energy and power densities as well as long cycle life at an affordable cost still remains a major scientific and technological challenge involving the fundamental chemistry and properties of radically new electrode and electrolyte materials and their scalable manufacturing for cost effectiveness. This award explores the scalable manufacturing of a new class of high-energy battery electrodes that incorporate functional nanostructured polymers with ultrahigh-capacity inorganic particles for high performing next generation lithium-ion batteries. This award research will provide a better fundamental understanding of chemical and electrochemical properties of hybrid inorganic-organic materials, and significantly advance the next generation of energy storage systems that are crucial to the renewable energy future of our society. Moreover, fundamental knowledge and manufacturing strategy gained will be useful for designing other electrochemical devices and systems such as fuel cells, photoelectrochemical cells, and electrochemical sensors. The education and outreach objective is to tightly integrate the renewable energy-centered research efforts and results with graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 education and to globally disseminate both research and education outcomes. The integrated research and education in this project will promote students, active learning and their excitement for sustainable energy research and future engineering career, and increase critically-needed efforts in education and workforce development related to sustainable energy.

New approaches towards the development of novel electrode materials with high capacity, low-cost, long cycle life and the ability to be produced at large scale, are critically needed in order to significantly advance the progress towards high energy/power density next-generation energy storage systems. This project focuses on rational design and scalable solution-based synthesis and device fabrication of a novel hierarchical battery electrode system that synergistically integrate nanostructured conductive polymers with inorganic particles to address fundamental challenges faced by ultrahigh-capacity inorganic electrode materials. The approaches are focused on (i) design and scalable synthesis of hierarchical inorganic-polymer electrodes (HIPE) with tunable structures for greatly enhanced energy storage capabilities, (ii) understanding their electronic and electrochemical properties, as well as studying the critical design issues including scalability and manufacturability, and (iii) fundamental investigation of electrochemical dynamics at the nanoscale hybrid interface through microscopic characterizations and mechanistic simulations. This research aimed from both scientific and engineering perspective will establish a new class of hybrid battery electrode systems for next-generation lithium battery technologies. The expected results will improve the knowledge of structural design at the molecular level for optimized electrochemical properties of these novel materials, and provide a deeper understanding of electrochemical dynamics at the nanoscale hybrid inorganic-organic interface. The partnership of academic researchers with national laboratory and technology company will help focus this fundamental research on practical issues and accelerate the nanomanufacturing scale-up.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efficient energy storage systems impact profoundly the renewable energy future of the US and around the world. Currently, the major barrier to producing cost-effective electric vehicles is the  limited progress on energy storage technologies. Moreover, grid-scale energy storage technology is important for enabling full utilization of renewable electricity generated from intermittent energy sources such as wind and solar. However, increasing the energy and power densities as well as the cycle life of energy storage devices at an affordable cost still remain a major technological challenge.

Outcomes of Intellectual Merit: This project aimed to develop a class of energy storage materials that integrate highly electroactive inorganic nanoparticles into functional organic/polymeric frameworks to enable superior electrochemical properties, for scalable high-performance electrochemical energy storage devices. Meanwhile this project may enable better fundamental understanding of electrochemical properties of hybrid inorganic-organic materials, and may advance the next generation of energy storage systems. We list below some of the research highlights.

1. Synthesis and characterization of hierarchical polymer framework materials with controlled structures and tunable chemical and electrochemical properties. For example, we developed a set of controlled nanostructures from interconnected 1D nanofiber networks to 3D networked conductive polymers, and we found the enhanced interchain charge transport of small molecule-doped conjugated polymers such as PPy resulted in greatly enhanced conductivity and electrochemical activities compared with pristine counterparts.

2. Understanding electrochemical dynamics and mechanical behaviors of hybrid inorganic-gel electrode systems through ex-situ/in-situ microscopic characterizations and mechanistic simulations. For instance, we used in-situ transmission electron microscopy to investigate the lithiation/delithiation kinetics of SiNPs coated with conductive polymer layer. We discovered that this coating layer can lead to ?self-delithiation? at different stages of lithiation due to the internal compressive stress generated at the interface.

3. Extend hybrid inorganic-gel materials towards making scalable electrodes or membrane materials for advanced Li-Sulfur batteries, liquid metal-based alkali-ion batteries, etc. For example, we developed highly scalable yet flexible nanostructured porous membranes via a facile phase inversion method for advancing Li-S battery technology.

Outcomes of Broader Impact:  Fundamental knowledge and manufacturing strategy gained from this research will be useful for designing other advanced electrochemical devices and systems such as fuel cells, photoelectrochemical cells, and electrochemical sensors. In terms of educational training, the PI has used this award to mentor three graduate students and six undergraduate REU students. The PI was also involved in many educational/outreach activities to promote STEM awareness at local schools, and worked closely with university-wide programs to reach out to K-12 students and attract students from under-represented groups to STEM disciplines in order to increase the diversity in science and engineering. The results of this project have led to several national student awards, 25 publications in reputable peer-reviewed journals, and numerous presentations at both national and international conferences and meetings.
